content:
(I haven't tried to solve it yet)

Good puzzle idea, well executed.

+1 for difficulty change from medium to hard, this seems tough.

Please mention in 3. Collision that a robot and a ghost can cross each other (swap places).

When you add padding in your code before printing, you don't check for resulting collisions, I believe in test The Useless Door and Validator 5 the robot and ghost share the same cell on move 5 and 6 respectively.

Consider adding a test case "So Close Yet So Far" where the last robot's path is significantly shorter than the ghost(s):
EAS............a

This is a preliminary review. I haven't performed a full review yet.

Input
* Please add "Three space-separated integers" after "Line 1:".

Constraints
* Please remove the final constraint. Response time differs from language to language for an ordinary (i.e. no viewer) puzzle.

Tags
* Please delete "Sci-Fi". I understand some non-learning tags have been used in some puzzles, but let's avoid those as much as possible.

Cases
* Test 1 and Validator 1 are the same. Please revise them so that they cover the same scenario but with slightly different inputs and outputs.

* Validator 6: Please remove the trailing newline from the input.

Thanks.

Some test cases for you to consider. These solutions *might* create time paradoxes according to your Rule 1.

Input 1:
9 7 2
#########
#......E#
####A####
#S.....b#
####B####
#......a#
#########

Output 1:
R R R R R R L L L U U R R R
W R R R D D R R R W W W W W

9 5 2
#########
#S...AB.#
#C#a#b#c#
#E#######
#########

Output 2:
R R D U L L L D D W
W R R R R D U R R D

9 5 2
#########
#.BS..A.#
#.#C#.#.#
#c#E#a#b#
#########

Output 3:
R R D D U U R R D D
L L D D U U R R D D

Input 4:
9 8 3
#########
#a#c...E#
#.##D####
#.##B####
#S......#
#.#####A#
#....dCb#
#########

Output 4:
U U U W W W W W W W W
D D R R R R R R W W W
R R R U U U L R R R R

Input 5:
9 8 2
#########
#a#c...E#
#.##D####
#.##B####
#S......#
#.#####A#
#....dCb#
#########

Output 5:
U U U D D D R R R U U U L R R R R
D D R R R R R R W W W W W W W W W
What happens if an action causes a robot to walk into a wall? Is that action invalid, or does the robot simply remain in place?
WIP! My first puzzle! I hope it's clear enough! :)

Also, for Validator 9, shouldn't the solution minimizing arrival time be:

R W W W W W W W W W W W W W
D D R D D D L L D D D R R R

Your first test gives incorrect output. The robot 'must' stand on the switch for the door to remain open. 
The only solution is with 3 Loops: 
R R R R R R W W W W
W R R R D D R R R W
W W R R R U U R R R

The map is great though, I named it 'Temporal Traffic Jam' :)
I'll have a look on the others later on, thanks for the feedback.
Done. Thanks!
Wow! Great catch! It seems I still have some optimizations to make around collision checks...thank you!

I see you have edited your code, but the output you got for test The Useless Door isn't quite right: you must also try to advance robot instead of delay it.

A faster(I don't know if it is the best) solution for that case is:
D D L L U U L L L L L
W L L D D L L L L L W

Edit:
probably better to do:
D D L L U U L L L L L
W L L D D W L L L L L

Yes, I saw that. :/ I tried the easy way first :)
There's still work to be done! But I think the new rule on “crossings” should make the task a little easier. Well, hopefully. :D

Ah sorry, I was a little quick to send an update.

While I am at it, here is a better one for that damned useless door:

D D L L U U L L L L L
W W D D L L L L L L L

(DDLLLLLLL becomes better than LLDDLLLLL once we add the ghost ..)

No problem! :)
Wow! You already have a solver? The previous result had already convinced me!! :D
It's really complex to guarantee THE unique solution manually, I'll try to write a script for direct evaluation of a test result... :/ I didn't think I'd reach this level of difficulty, but I think the puzzle is worth it! :D
Thanks for the help!
"You already have a solver?" You overestimate me, I did it mentally. :p
I've stopped trying, too much of a headache! :) I've just uploaded a new version! Fingers crossed! :)

Damn you are good, that's an impressive code update in such a short time.

The Deep Descent seems wrong with those extra Waits after the first two Right.
Not that much! I introduce new bugs with every version! :O I need to completely rethink collision management... I'm starting to think that my puzzle idea is beyond my skills! :D

Actually, I have doubts about the clarity of rule 4. (“A door is open for the entire loop if any ghost will stand on its corresponding switch at any point during that loop. This follows time loop logic: future actions are predetermined.”)
According to this rule, strictly speaking, I think the solution is valid. But it is clearly confusing.

What do you think would be the correct solution according to the ‘Polite Keymaster’ test?

W W R
R R R

or

W R W
R R R

or something else? :O
Oops, I didn't mean to say it wasn't a valid solution, I meant to say it wasn't the best as placing the W before the R is better lexicographically, so WWR >  WRW.

But WWR IS the current solution for the test ‘’'Keymaster'.
In fact, I'm trying to get your point "The Deep Descent seems wrong with those extra Waits after the first two Right." :D 

I thought this remark was due to the fact that in the “deep descent” (or ‘keymaster’) solution, a robot passed through a door at time T when it was not yet “open” at time T by the ghost. Damn, this is soooo confusing! :))

Any idea what the optimal result (according to the current rules) for “Deep descent” would be? :D

You brought "Keymaster" in the discussion, I am fine with it. :p

For Deep Descent, a better solution is:

W W W W W W D D R R R R
W W W W D D D D R R R R
W W D D D D D D R R R R
D D D D D D D D R R R R
.. is what I meant.

Oh, I'm confusing myself, I can't see straight anymore! :)
So we're all on aligned about the rules, my current solution isn't the right one! I'll get back to it asap! :)

I'm still not satisfied with my solver. I think I'm close to the timeout limit on some tests, but the results seem better! There's still a lot of work to be done to optimize it, but I don't want to go too far either :p

What do you think? :)

I think you are a madlad.

I just started to try to solve this puzzle, and I realised there is no test where max_loops is restrictive in any way (ie a test where the fastest way involves n loops, but we can only use n - 1 loops and doing so uses more steps) and I hope it will stay this way and we will both forget about ever reading this message. :)

I only started to solve it after you proved me it was playable, don't get our roles switched here. :D

An 'easy' time gain is to use a bitmap for the active switches instead of a set/list.
So you can do
bitmap & (1 << (switch - 'a')) to know if the switch is in your bitmap and
bitmap |= (1 << (switch - 'a')) to add a switch to your bitmap, with switch being a char from 'a' to 'z'.

And I use a second bitmap for the doors.

Ooh wait, I found the culprit! I still had a beam width of 2000!!! :O Now I have reasonable times!! 
But since your code is undoubtedly faster, you've earned the right to create the ultimate map for this puzzle! :)

Goal - Key Concepts
* "one robot's path": The phrase suggests there may be multiple robots active in a single loop, which is never the case. Consider replacing "one" with "a" for clarity.

* "that robot's path becomes a ghost…": It seems that the robot becomes a ghost, not the path itself. Consider rewriting the sentence as:

that robot becomes a ghost, which automatically replays the same sequence of moves in all subsequent loops.

Goal - Rules
* Please explain how a robot may move as the first rule. You could move the description of allowed actions (Down, Left, Right, Up, Wait) from the Output section into the Goal section, and then simply reference the abbreviated forms (D L R U W) in the Output section to avoid repetition.

* Please move the door activation rule to appear after the time loop and collision rules, because the door activation logic depends on understanding time loops first, and the collision rule must be satisfied first before we consider any door activation.

* For readability, please use sub-numbering (e.g. 5.1 and 5.2) for the two optimization criteria listed under Rule 5.

* Rule 5 explains how to break ties between solutions with the same number of moves. Please explicitly state how solutions with *different* numbers of moves are compared.

* Please clarify whether padding with {{W}} counts as actual moves (i.e. consumes turns) when determining the number of moves or total duration of a path. If so, please also state whether {{W}} moves occurring after a robot has already reached {{E}} are included in that count.

Output
* Please format "[[N]] lines" in <<bold>>.

Constraints
* Please add:
Every side of the grid is a wall.
The grid contains exactly one {{S}} and one {{E}}.
Each switch letter and each door letter appears exactly once, forming a one-to-one correspondence.
Every door is placed so that it blocks all possible routes through its location unless it is opened; it cannot be bypassed by walking around it.

* "The canonical solution is guaranteed to be unique." may be moved from the Goal section to the Constraints section.

Stub generator
* Please change 1024 to width.

Difficulty
* What's your rationale behind setting the difficulty rating as Medium? Do you think it could be increased to Hard?

Cases
* Please ensure that the cases are ordered by increasing difficulty (e.g. larger grids, more rules to apply, greater branching).

Solution
* Your code selects a solution based on `current_max_len`. This approach may not always yield the optimal result. For example, consider the following input:

12 7 2
############
#a..#.b....#
###.#####.##
#.....S....#
####A###B###
#......E...#
############

Activating Door B allows the robot to reach E in fewer turns, but your solution chooses to activate Door A. Have I missed anything?

Thanks.

Still a lot to review, I may have set the bar too high for my first puzzle! :D
Regarding the example given, the correct solution is indeed to go through door A. Both solutions are 8 characters long (don't forget the first WAIT in the second LOOP, because the robot and its ghost cannot share the same square). After the “custom” sort, the correct solution is door A. (Your solution could be the right one if I implement Use123's proposal -> "lexicographically largest path")

I think I've covered all the points! Thanks a lot for the feedback!

I guess you're right about the complexity, I'm terrible at estimating that kind of thing! 
The puzzle requires understanding temporal mechanisms (ghosts, door activation), pathfinding with time-dependent obstacles, and multi-loop coordination. The optimization rules (minimizing duration,...) add to the complexity. Most players will need a BFS with state tracking and pruning. So I guess “difficult” would be maybe more appropriate. My migraine, which inspired this puzzle, probably also makes it harder to understand! :D

I still need to rework the order of the tests. But everything is a bit relative. For my part, the ‘The Polite Keymaster’ test seemed complex to me in the sense that this necessary back-and-forth on S hadn't occurred to me at all during the design phase. 
I'm also thinking of removing the ‘Another Brick in The Wall’ test, which doesn't seem very relevant to me. All suggestions are welcome regarding the order or missing/extra tests! :)

No worries! @User123, other nice CodinGamers and I are here to help you! 😉

Here are my comments on the updated contribution (including the order of cases that you asked about):

Goal - Rules
* Rule 3: Please simplify the rule heading to "Collision".

* Rule 6: Consider removing the blank line immediately after the heading.

* Consider promoting the current note on turn counting to its own rule (i.e. Rule 6: Turn Counting), and renumbering the existing Rule 6 as Rule 7.

Cases
* Please add a wall below Door D so that the robot cannot walk around it:
  • Temporal Cascade (Test 8)
  • Validator 8

* I ran your code locally and recorded approximate execution times for all test cases:

  • Pairs 1, 2, 11: < 0.01 s
  • Pairs 3, 5, 7, 10 and Validator 4: 0.01-0.1 s
  • Test 4: 0.1-1 s
  • Pair 9: 1-2 s
  • Pair 7: 2-3 s
  • Pair 8: slightly over 3 s

  Based on this, you might consider:
  • Placing Pairs 10 and 11 earlier in the sequence.
  • Increasing the complexity of Validator 4 to better align with Test 4.
  • Ordering Pair 9 before Pairs 7 and 8.

  That said, execution time isn't the only factor in determining case order, so it's perfectly reasonable to deviate from the above suggestions if there are other design considerations.

With the right path:
R R R R D D L L L

I think there are two viable directions for test case design, and both can be adopted to create different cases for this puzzle:

1. A large number of switches and doors, but with little to no branching or backtracking.

2. A moderate number of switches and doors, but with increased branching and a genuine need for backtracking or clever BFS.

With careful construction, the first direction should be feasible. In such cases, the solver is not expected to explore anything close to 24! possibilities; instead, it effectively follows a largely scripted (relatively linear) activation sequence, keeping the BFS search space manageable.

The second direction is less certain and would require further experimentation to understand how much branching can be introduced without pushing the problem beyond its intended difficulty.

I don't think we need to limit ourselves only to the most "interesting" cases. The maximum allows 25 pairs, and we currently have 16 pairs. In general, more cases mean more robust coverage, especially for edge conditions and solver behaviour.

Right now, the progression in terms of switch/door count isn't very smooth and has some large gaps:

* 1 switch/door: 4 pairs
* 2 switches/doors: 4.5 pairs
* 3 switches/doors: 0.5 pair
* 4 switches/doors: 3 pairs
* 8 switches/doors: 1 pair
* 11 switches/doors: 1 pair
* >20 switches/doors: 2 pairs (after adding "Alphabet Hub")

This suggests we should be adding more cases (not limiting or reducing them) particularly to cover the moderate range (5 to 20 switches/doors), which is currently underrepresented.

When designing new cases, please also try to keep **balanced coverage** in mind:

* Use more grids where width isn't greater than height (i.e. width = height or width < height).
* Add at least one test where the exit is NW of the start (not present in current tests).
* Add at least one validator where the exit is NE of the start (not present in current validators).

Once the full set of cases is finalised, the case order will need to be revisited again to ensure a smooth difficulty progression.

Finally, there are issues in the current cases that need fixing:

* The Bunker (Test 14) and Validator 14:
  • More than one "q" is present.
  • "n" is present, but "N" is missing.

* Ephemeral Dedication (Test 15):
  • More than one "L" is present.

* Validator 15:
  • More than one "L" is present.
  • More than one "l" is present.

Please fix these cases, and I strongly recommend writing a small script to validate input grids (e.g. uniqueness of letters, door–switch pairing) to prevent this class of errors in the future.

Thanks.

This rule does not seem to apply for the current solution to test case "What a Maze!"

Yes it does. It's the magic of nonlinear causality! :D

In Loop 1: Robot 0 has become Ghost 0. It is its past presence on the switch that validates the opening condition for Robot 1.
That's why we need time loops: we can't help ourselves, we need help from our past!

In other words, a Robot can ONLY go through a door if one of its ghosts has activated the corresponding switch. It cannot activate a switch itself and go through that door. 
This forces temporal collaboration.

The statement certainly needs to be refined to properly explain this mechanism of causality.
I see, so doors only open for future time loops, not for past time loops. This answers my question in the other thread, thank you.

Looking at your suggestions, I see that we have the same interpretation of the rules (especially rule 4). But this rule seems a little confusing. I wonder if it shouldn't be adapted to a “more natural” rule -> door open at time T only if a ghost has already opened it at that same moment. Open question! :) (Personally, I liked the current idea, but it may be counterintuitive.)

I initially thought that a door being open only during and after the corresponding button has been pressed in a previous loop makes more intuitive sense! It might be slightly easier implementation wise too, although I've not yet started on my solution.

This is quite a core mechanic of your puzzle though; reworking this will lead to a lot of puzzles breaking. But on the other hand, it does encourage more creative puzzle solving techniques (e.g., when the sole path is blocked by a ghost; see "The Polite Keymaster").

I'm fine with the mechanics either way! I think it just takes some getting used to :)

I would rephrase the canonical solution section to clearly define the order in which to apply the three rules for comparing valid solutions. The three rules (based on what I understand so far), in order of priority, are as follows:

1) Minimising the total number of turns (turn length) taken by the robot across all time loops, which is equivalent to the length of the output.

2) If turn length is equal, then minimise the number of time loops required to escape the facility (i.e., the fewer number of lines of output required, the better). Note that this rule only applies IF multiple solutions have the same minimal turn length.

3) If both turn length and number of loops are equal, then (and only then) return the lexicographically largest output. This is defined by concatenating all paths across all time loops into one string, starting from the first time loop and ending at the last time loop (e.g., L R W W \n W L L L --> L R W W W L L L). There will only be one possible solution for this rule. Moreover, all concatenated strings in this rule will have the same length due to rules 1 and 2 above.

Oh sorry I misunderstood! :D
Yes sure, this will be more natural, you 're right!
